channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: Officer alleges LAPD had quotas, silenced whistleblowers in gang-labeling scandal
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector, Ben Poston
item.description: An officer in the LAPD's Metro Division alleges in a lawsuit that commanders have enforced a de facto quota system that rewarded officers who arrested a lot of alleged gang members.
item.content:encoded: An officer in the LAPD's Metro Division alleges in a lawsuit that commanders have enforced a de facto quota system that rewarded officers who arrested a lot of alleged gang members.

media:content.media:description: A woman who fell out of a moving Los Angeles police car has reached a settlement with the city and officers.

item.title: O.C. hopes history doesn't repeat itself as it anticipates reopening guidelines
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: Orange County is expected to receive the green light for in-person learning at all schools just before Labor Day if the county continues to remain off the state's watchlist.
item.content:encoded: Orange County is expected to receive the green light for in-person learning at all schools just before Labor Day if the county continues to remain off the state's watchlist.

media:content.media:description: A man wears a mask in Huntington Beach. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Lane Hirabayashi, scholar who refused to let Japanese American prison camps be forgotten, dies at 67
item.dc:creator: Steve Marble
item.description: A UCLA professor and one of the nation's leading authorities on the incarceration of Japanese Americans during World War II, Hirabayashi spent decades keeping memories of the prison camps alive.
item.content:encoded: A UCLA professor and one of the nation's leading authorities on the incarceration of Japanese Americans during World War II, Hirabayashi spent decades keeping memories of the prison camps alive.

media:content.media:description: Lane Ryo Hirabayashi

item.title: Family of Black man killed by Pasadena police file claims against city
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: Attorneys for the family of Anthony McClain say he was not armed when police shot him in the back as he ran.
item.content:encoded: Attorneys for the family of Anthony McClain say he was not armed when police shot him in the back as he ran.

item.title: New $300-a-week unemployment benefits coming soon, California officials say
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: Millions of Californians who are out of work during the COVID-19 pandemic will soon receive a $300 weekly supplemental unemployment benefit starting retroactive to Aug. 1, state officials said Monday.
item.content:encoded: Millions of Californians who are out of work during the COVID-19 pandemic will soon receive a $300 weekly supplemental unemployment benefit starting retroactive to Aug. 1, state officials said Monday.

media:content.media:description: Gov. Gavin Newsom discusses his revised 2019-2020 state budget during a news conference Thursday, May 9, 2019, in Sacramento, Calif. Newsom, a Democrat, has proposed a $213.5 billion a spending plan. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli)

item.title: Police unions ask Legislature to hold special session for reforms
item.dc:creator: Anita Chabria, Phil Willon
item.description: Police unions in Los Angeles and San Francisco Thursday asked Gov. Gavin Newsom to convene a special session of the Legislature before passing new reforms.
item.content:encoded: Police unions in Los Angeles and San Francisco Thursday asked Gov. Gavin Newsom to convene a special session of the Legislature before passing new reforms.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 26: A line of people hold their hands up as police form a line in the third street tunnel during a protest following the shooting of Jacob Blake in downtown on Wednesday, Aug. 26, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Dania Maxwell / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Rat poison kills bobcat, mountain lion in Southern California mountains
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: While mountain lions periodically succumb to the poisons, this is the first time in 23 years that a collared bobcat has died directly from the effects of rodenticides, officials say.
item.content:encoded: While mountain lions periodically succumb to the poisons, this is the first time in 23 years that a collared bobcat has died directly from the effects of rodenticides, officials say.

media:content.media:description: The body of B-372, an adult female bobcat, was found June 20, 2020, in Agoura Hills. Officials said she died from the effects of anticoagulant rat poisons.

item.title: Beverly Hills will prosecute protesters for curfew violations
item.dc:creator: James Queally
item.description: Beverly Hills is prosecuting 25 people arrested for alleged curfew violations even though L.A. County has declined to take such cases to court.
item.content:encoded: Beverly Hills is prosecuting 25 people arrested for alleged curfew violations even though L.A. County has declined to take such cases to court.

media:content.media:description: HOLLYWOOD, CALIFORNIA JUNE 6, 2020-A family member of Breonna Taylor, right, is hugged by another woman after speaking to protestors in beverly Hills Saturday. The protest was organzied by the Refuse Fascism group. (Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California Senate Republicans under COVID-19 quarantine, not allowed in state Capitol
item.dc:creator: Melody Gutierrez, Taryn Luna
item.description: The state Senate cancels session after Sen. Brian Jones (R-Santee) tests positive for coronavirus. Now he and many GOP lawmakers are under quarantine.
item.content:encoded: The state Senate cancels session after Sen. Brian Jones (R-Santee) tests positive for coronavirus. Now he and many GOP lawmakers are under quarantine.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this May 28, 2020, file photo, Sen. Holly Mitchell, D-Los Angeles, left, chair of the Senate Budget and Fiscal Review Committee, wears a face mask while standing behind a plexiglass barrier during a budget committee hearing in the Senate in Sacramento, Calif. On Wednesday, July 8, 2020, Secretary of the Senate Erika Contreras announced that, because of an increase in coronavirus cases, the Senate would not return from its summer recess on July 13. The Assembly announced on Monday it would also delay its return after five people who work in the Assembly tested positive for the coronavirus. Speaker Anthony Rendon's Office confirmed Wednesday that number is now at six confirmed cases. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, File)

item.title: Contra Costa County allows gyms, nail salons and massage services to reopen outdoors
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan
item.description: Though it's still on the state's coronavirus watchlist, Contra Costa County will now allow some personal-care services to operate outdoors.
item.content:encoded: Though it's still on the state's coronavirus watchlist, Contra Costa County will now allow some personal-care services to operate outdoors.

media:content.media:description: WALNUT CREEK, CALIFORNIA - JULY 21: Insignia Hair Salon stylist Regina Muslimova cleans her station after giving a haircut in the parking lot behind her salon on July 21, 2020 in Walnut Creek, California. The salon reopened its doors to clients for haircuts a day after California Gov. Gavin Newsom announced guidance for barbershops and hair salons to offer haircuts in an outdoor setting. According to the new guidelines, "outdoor operations may be conducted under a tent, canopy, or other sun shelter as long as no more than one side is closed, allowing sufficient outdoor air movement." (Photo by Justin Sullivan/Getty Images)

item.title: How Los Angeles is commemorating the 50th anniversary of the Chicano Moratorium
item.description: Fifty years after the Chicano Moratorium and the killing of journalist Ruben Salazar, marches, forums, screenings and more show the issues are still relevant.
item.content:encoded: Fifty years after the Chicano Moratorium and the killing of journalist Ruben Salazar, marches, forums, screenings and more show the issues are still relevant.

media:content.media:credit: Photo illustration by Martina Ibáñez-Baldor / Los Angeles Times. Photographs from from Los Angeles Times, Los Angeles Herald Examiner, Raul Ruiz, and Special Collections & Archives, John F. Kennedy Memorial Library, Cal State LA, Gloria Arellanes Papers.

item.title: 10 arrested after protesters clash with L.A. police in wake of Jacob Blake shooting
item.dc:creator: Luke Money, Richard Winton, Leila Miller
item.description: Several scuffles broke out and 10 people were arrested during a protest in downtown Los Angeles late Wednesday
item.content:encoded: Several scuffles broke out and 10 people were arrested during a protest in downtown Los Angeles late Wednesday

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA, August 26, 2020 - Protesters raise their hands as LAPD officers converge on them from both sides in the Third St. underpass. (Robert Gauthier / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California adopts major pollution cuts for diesel trucks and ships
item.dc:creator: Tony Barboza
item.description: California adopts biggest pollution-cutting regulations in more than a decade. Rules are equivalent to removing 16 million cars from state roads.
item.content:encoded: California adopts biggest pollution-cutting regulations in more than a decade. Rules are equivalent to removing 16 million cars from state roads.

media:content.media:description: SAN PEDRO CA. AUGUST 27, 2020 - Trucks line up to drop off their loads at the Port of Los Angeles in August 28, 2020. California air quality officials are poised to adopt their biggest pollution-cutting regulations in more than a decade, targeting diesel trucks and cargo ships that spew much of the state's cancer-causing and smog-forming emissions. The state Air Resources Board is expected to vote after a public hearing Thursday on two rules: one to establish stringent new emissions standards for heavy-duty diesel trucks and one to reduce pollution from ships docked at ports. (Genaro Molina/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. teacher flees home amid threats after wearing 'I can't breathe' T-shirt to online class
item.dc:creator: Nina Agrawal
item.description: The English teacher at El Camino Real Charter High School fears for her safety and has sought restraining orders after photos of her were shared widely on social media. Students and the teachers union have rallied in her support.
item.content:encoded: The English teacher at El Camino Real Charter High School fears for her safety and has sought restraining orders after photos of her were shared widely on social media. Students and the teachers union have rallied in her support.

media:content.media:description: WOODLAND HILLS, CA - AUGUST 26: Students and community members protest in front of El Camino Charter High School to show support a teacher who wore an 'I can't breathe' shirt while teaching a class on Wednesday, Aug. 26, 2020 in Woodland Hills, CA. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: L.A. Zoo reopens, but visitors have to stay one zebra apart
item.dc:creator: Priscella Vega
item.description: The Los Angeles Zoo is open again after closing for 166 consecutive days due to the coronavirus outbreak.
item.content:encoded: The Los Angeles Zoo is open again after closing for 166 consecutive days due to the coronavirus outbreak.

media:content.media:description: Meerkats look at the visitors to the reopening of the Los Angeles Zoo on Wednesday. The zoo had been closed since March 13, 2020 because of the coronavirus pandemic. The reopening conforms with the Los Angeles County Department of Public Health's safety protocols that include limited capacity, timed-ticketed entry, closure of indoor and high-touch spaces, requirements for face coverings and supplemental signage throughout the zoo.

item.title: Dodgers announcer Jaime Jarrín: Chicano Moratorium eyewitness
item.dc:creator: Kevin Baxter
item.description: Though he's known for announcing Dodger games in Spanish, Jaime Jarrín was honored for his coverage of the chaos of the Chicano Moratorium.
item.content:encoded: Though he's known for announcing Dodger games in Spanish, Jaime Jarrín was honored for his coverage of the chaos of the Chicano Moratorium.

media:content.media:description: SAN MARINO-CA-AUGUST 18, 2020: Dodger broadcaster Jaime Jarrin, left, and his son Jorge are photographed with their Golden Mike awards for excellence in radio news coverage at home in San Marino on Tuesday, August 18, 2020. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Many California police reform efforts have stalled despite push from George Floyd protests
item.dc:creator: Anita Chabria
item.description: Among the failed measures was a law that would have required fellow officers to intervene when they witness excessive force.
item.content:encoded: Among the failed measures was a law that would have required fellow officers to intervene when they witness excessive force.

media:content.media:description: BURBANK, CA - JUNE 04: Protest over police brutality and the death of George Floyd takes place in front of North Hollywood Police Station. Rally was organized by Showing up for Racial Justice (SURJ), an organization dedicated to organizing white folks across the nation to show up and fight the root causes of racism. North Hollywood Police Station on Thursday, June 4, 2020 in Burbank, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Through doll play, an L.A. therapist reminds Black girls of their innocence
item.dc:creator: Laura Newberry
item.description: A project in Los Angeles uses doll play to address the phenomenon of "adultification bias," a form of racial prejudice that can lead teachers and other authority figures to treat Black girls as more mature than they actually are.
item.content:encoded: A project in Los Angeles uses doll play to address the phenomenon of "adultification bias," a form of racial prejudice that can lead teachers and other authority figures to treat Black girls as more mature than they actually are.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, California-MARCH 5, 2020: Renee Curry, a therapist, leads a group of Crete Academy students during a therapy session at Crete Academy in Park Mesa Heights. For an hour each Thursday afternoon, the group of four or five girls play with dolls and talk about anything from their home dynamics to their friends at school. The idea is to give these girls a space to experience their own innocence in an attempt to at least partially address the effects of adultification bias (a form of racial prejudice where children of minority groups, particularly black girls, are treated as being more mature than they actually are by a reasonable social standard of development). (Gabriella Angotti-Jones/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Watch the L.A. Times Chicano Moratorium forum live
item.dc:creator: Times staff
item.description: This month the Times published a series of stories revisiting the 1970 Chicano Moratorium and its legacy. Join the discussion.
item.content:encoded: This month the Times published a series of stories revisiting the 1970 Chicano Moratorium and its legacy. Join the discussion.

item.title: Workers and customers are catching COVID-19. Should businesses escape blame?
item.dc:creator: Margot Roosevelt
item.description: Businesses fear they'll be blamed for COVID-19's spread. They're fighting for measures to protect them from lawsuits over infections, hospitalizations and deaths.
item.content:encoded: Businesses fear they'll be blamed for COVID-19's spread. They're fighting for measures to protect them from lawsuits over infections, hospitalizations and deaths.

media:content.media:description: COMPTON, CA - AUGUST 12: Henry Ephraim poses for a portrait outside the Ralphs/Food 4 Less distribution center in Compton where he says he caught the coronavirus due to the companies failure to institute safety measures for its workers on Wednesday, Aug. 12, 2020 in Compton, CA. (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Coronavirus has turned once-bustling downtown L.A. into a ghost town. Can it recover?
item.dc:creator: Thomas Curwen
item.description: For 10 years, downtown L.A. was booming with a youthful, renegade vibe. The coronavirus puts those hard-won gains at risk.
item.content:encoded: For 10 years, downtown L.A. was booming with a youthful, renegade vibe. The coronavirus puts those hard-won gains at risk.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUG. 6, 2020. A man pushes a shopping cart along the sidewalk in the historc urban core of Los Angeles on Thursday, Aug. 6, 2020. Motor and foot traffic downtown has thinned considerably since the pre-coronavirus days of five months ago. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Magnitude 3.5 quake reported near Ukiah, Calif.
item.dc:creator: Quakebot
item.description: A magnitude 3.5 earthquake was reported at 1:48 a.m. Thursday 13 miles from Ukiah, Calif., according to the U.S. Geological Survey.
item.content:encoded: A magnitude 3.5 earthquake was reported at 1:48 a.m. Thursday 13 miles from Ukiah, Calif., according to the U.S. Geological Survey.

media:content.media:description: A magnitude 3.5 earthquake was reported 13 miles from Ukiah, Calif., on Thursday.

item.title: Skelton: Newsom proves he's no deer in headlights while managing several crises 'of biblical proportions'
item.dc:creator: George Skelton
item.description: Now wildfires and blackouts are piled on top of a COVID-19 pandemic — a strange virus that has infected more than 680,000 people and killed more than 12,000 in California. You'd think that might place any governor at political risk, but it apparently hasn't.
item.content:encoded: Now wildfires and blackouts are piled on top of a COVID-19 pandemic — a strange virus that has infected more than 680,000 people and killed more than 12,000 in California. You'd think that might place any governor at political risk, but it apparently hasn't.

media:content.media:description: Aug. 17, 2020 - California Gov. Gavin Newsom briefing on the power outages in the state due to extreme heat.

item.title: Former San Bernardino County sheriff's deputy charged with assault, theft while on duty
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: A former San Bernardino County sheriff's deputy faces criminal charges for hitting a man with a baseball bat, filing a false police report and stealing from a Big 5 Sporting Goods store during unrest in June after the death of George Floyd
item.content:encoded: A former San Bernardino County sheriff's deputy faces criminal charges for hitting a man with a baseball bat, filing a false police report and stealing from a Big 5 Sporting Goods store during unrest in June after the death of George Floyd

item.title: L.A. County CEO to receive $1.5 million and security in settlement over alleged harassment by sheriff
item.dc:creator: Jaclyn Cosgrove, Alene Tchekmedyian
item.description: Set to retire Monday, L.A. County Chief Executive Sachi Hamai will receive $1.5 million and private security services to address concerns for her personal safety, according to a settlement agreement and a letter sent to county supervisors.
item.content:encoded: Set to retire Monday, L.A. County Chief Executive Sachi Hamai will receive $1.5 million and private security services to address concerns for her personal safety, according to a settlement agreement and a letter sent to county supervisors.

media:content.media:description: LA County agrees to pay $1.5 million to Sachi Hamai after she was harassed by Sheriff Alex Villanueva.

item.title: O.C. sheriff's sergeant accidentally fires weapon at airport, injuring employee

item.description: An Orange County sheriff's sergeant accidentally fired his weapon in the John Wayne Airport on Wednesday morning, injuring an airport employee.
item.content:encoded: An Orange County sheriff's sergeant accidentally fired his weapon in the John Wayne Airport on Wednesday morning, injuring an airport employee.

item.title: Police in L.A. region announce dozens of arrests and ongoing pursuit of suspects from summer unrest

item.content:encoded: Police from across the Los Angeles region announced Wednesday the arrests of dozens of people on arson, burglary and looting charges stemming from the unrest of late May and early June.

item.title: Protesters march in downtown L.A. over Jacob Blake shooting
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: Hundreds of protesters rallied near the Hall of Justice in downtown L.A. on Wednesday evening as nationwide demonstrations continue over the police shooting of Jacob Blake and the killing of two people at a protest in Kenosha, Wis.
item.content:encoded: Hundreds of protesters rallied near the Hall of Justice in downtown L.A. on Wednesday evening as nationwide demonstrations continue over the police shooting of Jacob Blake and the killing of two people at a protest in Kenosha, Wis.

Care's blood drive in downtown Los Angeles on Tuesday, Aug. 25, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. The Red Cross recently announced that it had a ``dangerous drop in blood supply'' due to the more than 30,000 blood drives that have been canceled since March because of the COIVID-19 pandemic. (Gabriella Angotti-Jones / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Securing The Times' Pulitzer-winning Latino series for future generations
item.dc:creator: Denise Florez
item.description: The Times won a Pulitzer for its 1983 project chronicling the lives of Southern California Latinos. It wasn't a part of our digital archive, until now.
item.content:encoded: The Times won a Pulitzer for its 1983 project chronicling the lives of Southern California Latinos. It wasn't a part of our digital archive, until now.

media:content.media:description: Images from the Los Angeles Times 1984 Pulitzer Prize Award for Public Service, "Latinos", a 27-part series on Southern California's latino community and culture in the early 1980s. April 3, 1983 Boyle Heights, CA. Old woman at Hollenbeck Park in Boyle Heights. (Los Angeles Times / Jose Galvez)

item.title: An L.A. politico helped select the new postmaster general. Why protesters are at his door
item.dc:creator: James Rainey
item.description: John M. Barger is brother to Supervisor Kathryn Barger and a Republican donor. As a Postal Service governor, his life is suddenly filled with complaints and picketers.
item.content:encoded: John M. Barger is brother to Supervisor Kathryn Barger and a Republican donor. As a Postal Service governor, his life is suddenly filled with complaints and picketers.

media:content.media:description: SAN MARINO, CA - AUGUST 22: Protesters rally outside the home of USPS Board of Governors John M. Barger to decry recent U.S. Postal Service cuts by Postmaster General Louis DeJoy that could effect presidential election mail-in ballots on August 22, 2020 in San Marino, California. The protesters say that John Barger, a GOP donor appointed to the Postal Service Board of Governors by President Trump, is responsible for appointing Louis DeJoy to be the Postmaster General. The demonstration is one of many post office rallies spread across the region to reduce the crowd size at any single location because of COVID-19 safety concerns. (Photo by David McNew/Getty Images)

item.title: They were prepped for flames, but the fire came too fast. They couldn't outrun it
item.dc:creator: Anita Chabria
item.description: This family had a fire bunker and plentiful water. But a pair of LNU complex fires converged and overran their escape. Relatives see it as a lesson for others.
item.content:encoded: This family had a fire bunker and plentiful water. But a pair of LNU complex fires converged and overran their escape. Relatives see it as a lesson for others.

media:content.media:description: NAPA, CA - AUGUST 25: Burnt out wreckage at a property along CA-128 where the LNU Lightning complex fire tore through last week, photographed on Tuesday, Aug. 25, 2020 in Napa, CA. McNeal said his mother, Mary Hintemeyer, her boyfriend Leo McDermott and his son, Tom McDermott took refuge from the LNU Lightning Complex Fire in a makeshift fire shelter on their Napa County property, but the trio never made it out alive.

item.title: UC Berkeley chancellor calls reopening amid crises 'hardest situation I've ever encountered'
item.dc:creator: Teresa Watanabe
item.description: As UC Berkeley prepares to start fall classes, Chancellor Carol Christ says reopening amid three crises is "the hardest situation I've ever encountered."
item.content:encoded: As UC Berkeley prepares to start fall classes, Chancellor Carol Christ says reopening amid three crises is "the hardest situation I've ever encountered."

media:content.media:description: August 15, 2017. BERKELEY, CA. New UC Berkeley Chancellor Carol Christ, the first woman to lead the nation's top public research university during news conference, greeting students and speaking during the convocation on a busy day of orientation for the freshman class. Photo by David Butow/for the Times

item.title: O.C.'s bishop, a $12-million problem and a secret fight stretching to the Vatican

item.description: A circle of influential Catholic philanthropists has complained to the Vatican about Bishop Kevin Vann, alleging he broke state law by removing them from an independent foundation.
item.content:encoded: A circle of influential Catholic philanthropists has complained to the Vatican about Bishop Kevin Vann, alleging he broke state law by removing them from an independent foundation.

media:content.media:description: Just a year after the Roman Catholic Diocese of Orange dedicated Christ Cathedral in Garden Grove, some of its most influential philanthropists are at war with the bishop.

item.title: Coronavirus takes a toll on Latinos — and the funeral homes that serve them

item.content:encoded: As the coronavirus ravages California's Latino communities, the grim cycle of illness and death ends at places like Continental Funeral Home.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA, August 21, 2020 -Continental Funeral Home driver Manuel Aguilar handles one of the Covid-19 victims held stored in a mobile refrigerator outside the facility. In the throes of the Covid-19 epidemic Continental struggles to keep up with the demands of rising death rates in a community suffering with health and finances. On this date, they had 112 decedents, 36 of them Covid-19. (Robert Gauthier / Los Angeles Times)

item.description: Northern California wildfires rage through the region with possible more on the way
item.content:encoded: Northern California wildfires rage through the region with possible more on the way

media:content.media:description: TOPSHOT - In this long exposure photograph, embers fly off a burning tree during the Hennessey fire in the Spanish Flat area of Napa, California on August 18, 2020. - As of the late hours of August 18, the Hennessey fire has merged with at least 7 fires and is now called the LNU Lightning Complex fires. Dozens of fires are burning out of control throughout Northern California as fire resources are spread thin. (Photo by JOSH EDELSON / AFP) (Photo by JOSH EDELSON/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: FBI boss gone from L.A. after watchdog finds top agents got exclusive Dodgers playoff seats

item.content:encoded: FBI agents' use of exclusive seating and a buffet violated federal ethics regulations and FBI policy, a watchdog's report concluded.

item.title: Young Black activist's arrest during George Floyd protest in San Luis Obispo sparks a new movement
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Brown
item.description: A rally and news conference were held Tuesday for 20-year-old activist Tianna Arata, who was arrested during an antiracism protest last month in San Luis Obispo.
item.content:encoded: A rally and news conference were held Tuesday for 20-year-old activist Tianna Arata, who was arrested during an antiracism protest last month in San Luis Obispo.

media:content.media:description: SAN LUIS OBISPO, CA - AUGUST 25: 20-year-old activist Tianna Arata addresses a rally Tuesday on the steps of the San Luis Obispo County Courthouse as supporters rally to protest her arrest following an anti-racism protest that allegedly ended in car vandalism on July 21, 2020 in San Luis Obispo that has sparked a national outcry. Arata was arrested on multiple felony accounts, but was subsequently released later that evening. The district attorney's office is currently reviewing Arata's case to determine what her charges will be. Her arraignment is set for Sept. 3. Today's rally was hosted by the Free Tianna Coalition, which is backed by BLM co-founder Patrisse Cullors. Courthouse on Tuesday, Aug. 25, 2020 in San Luis Obispo, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Son of Kareem Abdul-Jabbar charged with stabbing neighbor
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller

media:content.media:description: CELEBRITY FAMILY FEUD - "Harvey Family Men vs Harvey Family Women and Kareem Abdul-Jabbar vs Ralph Sampson"- The celebrity teams competing to win cash for their charities features Steve Harvey's wife, Marjorie Harvey, leading a team with their sons and sons-in-law, and the other team will be led by Mrs. Harvey's mother and the Harvey daughters. In a separate game, family members from the NBA's all-time leading scorer and six-time NBA champion Kareem Abdul-Jabbar will take on retired NBA Legend Ralph Sampson and his family. This episode of "Celebrity Family Feud" airs SUNDAY, JUNE 25 (8:00-9:00 p.m. EDT), on The Walt Disney Television via Getty Images Television Network.. (Eric McCandless/Walt Disney Television via Getty Images) STEVE HARVEY, KAREEM ABDUL-JABBAR, ADAM ABDUL-JABBAR, ROSE-ANN SWANN

media:content.media:description: EXCLUSIVE: June 17, 2019 - San Diego, California, United States: Sikorsky S76, tail number N72EX, piloted by Ara Zobayan. On January 26, 2020, Kobe Bryant and his daughter Gianna were among nine people on board when this Sikorsky crashed in a Calabasas mountain area killing all passengers and the pilot. (Polaris) ///

item.title: Squaw Valley ski resort to drop 'squaw' from name
item.dc:creator: Hugo Martín
item.description: Squaw Valley Alpine Meadows, near Lake Tahoe, plans to drop the derogatory term 'squaw' from its name.
item.content:encoded: Squaw Valley Alpine Meadows, near Lake Tahoe, plans to drop the derogatory term 'squaw' from its name.

media:content.media:description: The Olympic rings stand atop a sign at the entrance to the Squaw Valley Ski Resort in Olympic Valley, Calif., July 8, 2020. California's Squaw Valley Ski Resort is considering changing its name to remove "squaw," a derogatory term for Native American women. Squaw Valley President & CEO Ron Cohen says resort officials are meeting with shareholders and the local Washoe tribal leadership to get their input. He says he can't give a timeline on when the decision will be made. The renaming of Squaw Valley Ski Resort is one of many efforts across the nation to address colonialism and indigenous oppression. (AP Photo/Haven Daley)

item.title: FBI assisting in search for L.A. firefighter missing in Mexico

item.title: The coronavirus gave them jobs — and a new lease on life
item.dc:creator: Doug Smith
item.description: Some just got out of prison; others came off the streets. They are practically unemployable. But thanks to COVID-19, an L.A. nonprofit is able to put them to work at hotels taken over to house the homeless during the pandemic.
item.content:encoded: Some just got out of prison; others came off the streets. They are practically unemployable. But thanks to COVID-19, an L.A. nonprofit is able to put them to work at hotels taken over to house the homeless during the pandemic.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 21, 2020 - - Guest services associate Mia Rogers, 23, left, gives Project Roomkey guest Stanley Monk, 58, his lunch under the watchful eye of LVN Richard F. at a Project Roomkey hotel in Los Angeles on July 22, 2020. Rogers, a client of Chrysalis, lost her job due to the coronavirus pandemic. She was hired to work at a Project Roomkey hotel. About 100 clients of Chrysalis, a downtown agency that gets work for homeless people who lost their jobs because of the virus shutdowns. They've been rehired by Project Roomkey to work in hotels. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Ban on flavored tobacco sales is approved by California Assembly
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: The California Assembly on Monday approved a ban on the retail sale of flavored tobacco products in the state, with supporters saying it is needed to reduce smoking and vaping by minors and others attracted by fruit and menthol flavors.
item.content:encoded: The California Assembly on Monday approved a ban on the retail sale of flavored tobacco products in the state, with supporters saying it is needed to reduce smoking and vaping by minors and others attracted by fruit and menthol flavors.

item.title: USC reports 'alarming increase' in COVID-19 cases
item.dc:creator: Nina Agrawal

item.content:encoded: Just a week into fall semester, USC reported that 43 students had tested positive for COVID-19 and more than100 placed in quarantine because of exposure.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 17, 2020 - - USC student Jesus Carreon, 21, locks up his bike under a sign that states three steps to keep the coronavirus at bay on the first day of academic instruction for the Fall 2020 semester on the USC campus in Los Angeles on August 17, 2020. Carreon wanted to do his homework on a nearby patio to have some semblance of a college experience. Students were taking online courses off campus due to the coronavirus pandemic and the university was nearly empty. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: More counties removed from California's COVID-19 watchlist

item.content:encoded: Three more counties came off California's COVID-19 watchlist over the weekend after showing a decline in case counts and transmission rates for three consecutive days.

media:content.media:credit: Office of the Governor of California

item.title: When can schools reopen? What you need to know about waivers and watch lists
item.dc:creator: Nina Agrawal, Paloma Esquivel
item.description: Orange County hopes to be able to allow all K-12 schools to reopen but must stay off the state's watchlist. L.A. County is a different story.
item.content:encoded: Orange County hopes to be able to allow all K-12 schools to reopen but must stay off the state's watchlist. L.A. County is a different story.

media:content.media:description: Corona del Mar High School in Newport Beach.

item.title: USC Keck School of Medicine dean to step down after 3 years
item.dc:creator: Matt Hamilton
item.description: The dean of the Keck School of Medicine will leave her post after not quite three years, USC announced on Monday.
item.content:encoded: The dean of the Keck School of Medicine will leave her post after not quite three years, USC announced on Monday.

media:content.media:description: Laura Mosqueda, M.D., left, and Kerry Burnight, Ph.D., both professors with the Division of Geriatric Medicine and Gerontology pose for a portrait at their office in Orange on Tuesday.

item.title: California's top court overturns Scott Peterson's death sentence
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan
item.description: The California Supreme Court overturned Peterson's death sentence for killing his wife and unborn son. The penalty portion of his case may be retried.
item.content:encoded: The California Supreme Court overturned Peterson's death sentence for killing his wife and unborn son. The penalty portion of his case may be retried.

media:content.media:description: Laci Peterson, pictured with her husband Scott Peterson in an undated photo.

item.title: It's 8/24, and Kobe Bryant Day includes naming of street for him
item.dc:creator: Chuck Schilken, Dan Loumena
item.description: A day after he would have turned 42, Kobe Bryant is remembered on Monday, 8/24, including the naming of a Los Angeles street in his honor.
item.content:encoded: A day after he would have turned 42, Kobe Bryant is remembered on Monday, 8/24, including the naming of a Los Angeles street in his honor.

media:content.media:description: Kobe Bryant poses for a photo at the Beverly Hills Hilton on July 18, 2014. Bryant was limited to 35 games during the 2014-15 season because of injury.

item.title: How COVID-19 and budget woes have changed what 'back to school' means at Cal State
item.dc:creator: Nina Agrawal
item.description: The Cal State system announced in early May that it would go all virtual in the fall, but plans for instruction and student services vary by campus and county.
item.content:encoded: The Cal State system announced in early May that it would go all virtual in the fall, but plans for instruction and student services vary by campus and county.

media:content.media:description: FULLERTON, CA - AUGUST 21: Brett Nickman power washes benches in preparation of reopening for Fall Semester 2020 at Cal State University of Fullerton on Friday, Aug. 21, 2020 in Fullerton, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Shyong: Kamala Harris' identity shows us the limits of our labels
item.dc:creator: Frank Shyong
item.description: It was just the Tamil word for auntie, two syllables in a speech by Kamala Harris last Thursday that covered her childhood, heritage and political awakening and culminated in her acceptance of the Democratic Party nomination for vice president.
item.content:encoded: It was just the Tamil word for auntie, two syllables in a speech by Kamala Harris last Thursday that covered her childhood, heritage and political awakening and culminated in her acceptance of the Democratic Party nomination for vice president.

media:content.media:description: Kamala Harris, back row from left, with grandparents Rajam Gopalan and P.V. Gopalan and sister Maya Harris. In front are Maya's daughter, Meena, left, and the Harrises' cousin Sharada Balachandran Orihuela

item.title: In a rural California town, schools try something extraordinary and risky: Classrooms with children
item.dc:creator: Hailey Branson-Potts
item.description: In a vast, rural Northern California county with few cases of COVID-19, a public school district reopened to in-classroom instruction, even as most in the state are doing virtual distance learning.
item.content:encoded: In a vast, rural Northern California county with few cases of COVID-19, a public school district reopened to in-classroom instruction, even as most in the state are doing virtual distance learning.

media:content.media:description: WEAVERVILLE, CA - AUGUST 17: Darsi Green speaks to students in her second grade glass at Weaverville Elementary School on the first day on returning to in-person instruction on Monday, Aug. 17, 2020 in Weaverville, CA. The Trinity Alps Unified School District reopened amid the coronavirus pandemic, resuming in-person classroom instruction. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: Landlords need to stop whining about the unfairness of California's eviction ban
item.dc:creator: Erika D. Smith
item.description: With millions at risk of eviction, renters must come first as California's governor and lawmakers try to reach a legislative compromise with landlords.
item.content:encoded: With millions at risk of eviction, renters must come first as California's governor and lawmakers try to reach a legislative compromise with landlords.

media:content.media:description: Protestors held a press conference outside San Diego City Hall demanding that the City Council vote to extend the eviction moratorium amidst the fallout from the coronavirus pandemic on June 30, 2020 in San Diego, California.
media:content.media:credit: Sam Hodgson / The San Diego Union-Tribune

item.title: Northern California fires rage on: 'We are essentially living in a mega fire era'
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Luke Money, Alex Wigglesworth, Joe Mozingo
item.description: Firefighters saw a welcome respite in dangerous fire weather with the cancellation of a red-flag warning for the Bay Area.
item.content:encoded: Firefighters saw a welcome respite in dangerous fire weather with the cancellation of a red-flag warning for the Bay Area.

media:content.media:description: BEN LOMOND, CA - AUGUST 21: Firefighters work to contain a blaze during the CZU August Lightning Complex Fires on Friday, Aug. 21, 2020 in Ben Lomond, CA. The University of California at Santa Cruz campus and nearby towns have been under evacuation orders due to fires in the region. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Death of an Indigenous essential worker sparks debate over gender identity
item.dc:creator: Tomás Mier
item.description: Angela Martinez said she was neither man, nor woman, nor transgender. She was muxe, a third gender recognized in the Zapotec culture in Mexico.
item.content:encoded: Angela Martinez said she was neither man, nor woman, nor transgender. She was muxe, a third gender recognized in the Zapotec culture in Mexico.

media:content.media:description: RESEDA, CA - AUGUST 18: Portrait of Pink Moon Midnight Blue holding a photo of her friend Angela Martinez, left, on Tuesday, Aug. 18, 2020 in Reseda, CA. Pink Moon Midnight Blue, was a close friend of Angela Martinez, who died recently of COVID. Martinez identified herself as "muxe," third gender recognized by the Zapotec indigenous community in Mexico. Midnight Blue is transgender and said Martinez pointedly said she was neither man, nor woman, nor trans, but muxe. Midnight Blue is wearing a dress given to her by Martinez. She said Martinez was like a mother to her. (Francine Orr / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Skelton: California is too dependent on the rich. Now isn't the time for another millionaires' tax
item.dc:creator: George Skelton
item.description: The top 1% of California taxpayers kick in nearly half the state income tax. California is already leaning very heavily on its richest citizens — too heavily for good tax policy.
item.content:encoded: The top 1% of California taxpayers kick in nearly half the state income tax. California is already leaning very heavily on its richest citizens — too heavily for good tax policy.

media:content.media:description: Large boxes full of already opened and emptied envelopes sit at the Franchise Tax Board before being recycled in Sacramento. The last six months generated $2 billion more income tax revenue than expected, according to a new report from the nonpartisan Legislative Analyst's Office.
